data.title: Add StartSequence to WithIdleOverlay & change V19.Husk
data.body:
V19.Husk uses RenderBuilding & WithSpriteBody which implement IQuantizeBodyOrientation.
The problem is that `self.Info.Traits.GetOrDefault<IQuantizeBodyOrientationInfo>()` is called in BodyOrientation. While this probably has no noticeable affect on the game, it can be fixed simply by adding these two lines.

data.title: Alter install logic to convert case of file names
data.body: I had issues with music not being available after installing the TS content from the original disc. Made some simple changes to the YAML so case sensitive OSes should work too!

data.title: Aligns observer support power timers to the left edge of the screen.
data.body:
Since observers don't have support power icons, countdown timers can be aligned to the left edge of the screen. This PR removes the timer widget definition from ingame.yaml and adds it to ingame-observer.yaml and ingame-player.yaml. This way, the bounds can be defined separately for players and observers. It also removes the unused widget definition from d2k yaml.

This is split from #8619.

data.title: Throttle AI order speed to prevent lag spikes
data.body:
Fixes #8466
Fixes #8384
Fixes #4584
## Issue

In games with AI, as the game progresses there will start to be lag spikes every ~1 second. The spikes get worse with more AI.
## Cause

AIs re-evaluate their current state at set intervals. For example [assigning of roles](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/7d56209f3b772ea847cc8c9decb4c33cc4210e7d/OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/HackyAI.cs#L40-L41) and [updating of squads](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/7d56209f3b772ea847cc8c9decb4c33cc4210e7d/OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/HackyAI.cs#L46-L47). You'll notice both of these are 20/30 ticks - which are both roughly 1 second.

Luckily, evaluating AI state is fast.

What happens then is that the AIs issue new orders to be carried out. In a typical case they might issue say 10 orders to one of the squads to attack.

Luckily, issuing orders is fast.

[These orders are processed during the tick by the order manager](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/7d56209f3b772ea847cc8c9decb4c33cc4210e7d/OpenRA.Game/Network/OrderManager.cs#L212).

Luckily, processing orders is fast.

[Each time an order is processed, a hash of the world state must be generated for sync purposes](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/7d56209f3b772ea847cc8c9decb4c33cc4210e7d/OpenRA.Game/Network/OrderManager.cs#L213). This allows clients to identify the order responsible in the event of a desync.

Unluckily, hashing the world state is extremely slow.

In games with several AI, a few AI will decide to send orders to their squads, each squad needing maybe a dozen orders. They do this all at the exact same tick. This results in a flood of orders (say about 50 orders instead of the more usual 0-5) to be processed in a single tick. Hashing the world state so many times as a result of processing the orders is the reason for the lag spike.
## The Fix

I address this issue by limiting the ability of the AI to generate a flood of orders in a single tick. Instead, I spread out the orders over several ticks.

The first commit makes each AI in the game operate on different ticks. In games with lots of AI, this prevents them teaming up to make one tick very slow.

The second limits the number of orders an AI can issue per tick. Extra orders are queued up and processed on subsequent ticks. This prevents spikes from issuing orders to entire squads at once by forcing the AI to order each unit on separate ticks.

This throttling means that orders might be outdated by the time they are issued. This seems to work in my testing but somebody who knows how orders work better than I do should confirm I'm not introducing a massive chance for crashes and/or desyncs.
## Results

Perf graphs before and after (we care about the teal line representing tick_time)

![Perf Graph Comparion](http://i.imgur.com/SU5a0Lo.png)

You can check this yourself by just spectating a game with a large number of AI. Wait a few minutes until they start attacking each other and the lag spikes should appear. With this PR they should be prevented.

data.title: Remove ESC hotkey from lobby 'Back' button
Some work on Attack*
data.body:
Some rewiring (not a full refactor) in the attacking mechanism to accommodate using different cursors and voices with different armaments, as well as combining beneficial (buffs) and damaging weapons for a single actor.

Eliminates the need for the medic to subclass `AttackFrontal` and `AutoHeal` or use `Heal`.

I'll type up the upgrade rule after review of other code.

Discussed to some extent in #8763. Prerequisite for #8563.

data.title: AttackMedic and AutoHeal duplicates the logic of AttackFrontal and AutoTarget
data.body:
Currently we have a duplicate logic for healers. This means that if a unit wants to be a healers/active buffer with a damaging weapon as well, the unit can either resort to force-fire to heal/buff (along with forcing the damaging weapons to not work on allies to make sure it won't get fired along with the bufferweapon) via using the right Attack\* or just split the functionality of and use purely `AttackMedic` etc.

This also means that healer/buffers are hardcoded to have "`AttackFrontal`".

What I'd propose that instead of the duplication logic, there would be some kind of a `Benefical` tag on the weapon and `AutoTarget` would look at that - if `Benefical=yes`, allied autotargeting is allowed with that weapon, if no, enemy autotargeting is allowed on that weapon.
#8563 is a case where this becomes a problem.

data.title: Release file handles when unmounting file system
data.body:
Make `IFolder` implement `IDisposable`, and fix all concrete classes to dispose any streams they open.

When a folder is unmounted from `GlobalFileSystem`, dispose the folder to ensure all the streams are released in a timely manner.

This prevents us eating up file handles longer than we should be, but as a secondary effect also means we'll avoid having multiple open file streams to the same file. It's a long shot, that might help with #2441 if having multiple streams is somehow causing occasional garbage reads (I doubt it - but on the other hand the only-occasionally-broken weirdness of #2441 is so crazy that maybe the solution is more crazy).

Tested by loading the game and switching between all the mods.

[Diff ignoring whitespace](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8762/files?w=1)

data.title: Added [I]RangeMultiplier & made UpgradeMultiplierTraitInfo implement ITraitInfo
data.body:
RangeMultiplier as requested by @GraionDilach.
Also includes making UpgradeMultiplierTraitInfo implement ITraitInfo since it is implied by semantics and a small change to attack activities.

data.title: Improved AI BaseBuilder
data.body:
This improves 3 things:

**1. The low power check.** 
Previously, it would check whether players' `ExcessPower` was less than `MinimumExcessPower` or whether the sum of all `Power` traits on the structure it wanted to build _exceeded_ the players' `ExcessPower`, and if either was true, build a power plant instead.
The catch: power _draw_ is represented by _negative_ numbers, so the only structures that would trigger the 2nd check were - power plants.
In other words, as long as current `ExcessPower` was equal or higher than `MinimumExcessPower`, the whole check would effectively fail, hence why the AI was out of power about half the time before I introduced `MinimumExcessPower` recently.
Now the 2nd check properly evaluates whether current `ExcessPower` + to-build actors' `Power` would be _lower_ than `MinimumExcessPower`, and in that case build a power plant instead.
Additionally, unlike before, it now also performs the "do I have enough power" check for the higher-priority overrides (refineries, production buildings, silos).
Last but not least, it now also gives powerplants priority if already on low power (no idea why it was different before).

**2. Repeated placement failures.**
Previously, the AI would constantly and stubbornly retry to build and place a structure even if out of space.
Now, after 3 consecutive failed attempts to place a structure, it is assumed that the AI has run out of build space and further production of structures is paused for a minute (default value of `StructureProductionResumeDelay`) and only resumed if the number of buildings decreased (or number of construction yards increased) in the meantime.

**3. Placement failure of naval structures.**
Previously, the AI would try to build naval structures even if there was no water within the buildable area. Now it first checks whether there is enough water in the base perimeter, and disables production of naval buildings if not. 
If there is actually such water space, when deciding whether to build a naval structure it checks if a building providing buildable area is close enough to that water. Only if that condition is met as well, the naval structure will be produced.

In summary, this should considerably reduce lag spikes from repeated building placement failures (particularly if it runs out of space) and finally prevent the AI reliably from driving itself into low power.

Fixes #8116, mostly adresses #4717.

data.title: Fix #8751 - IndexOutOfRangeException when UpgradeMultiplierTrait is pre-enabled
data.body: Fixes #8751

data.title: Mod RA has so much lag it's unplayable
data.body:
Play mod RA on any large map and eventually the game freezes for 5 seconds every 3 seconds or so.
With many debug messages similar to: AI (X) has nowhere to place apwr.

The freeze is so bad it is simply unplayable.

How about stopping the AI from trying the same thing over and over again every 5 seconds?
If something failed once, try again in 10 seconds, failed again, try again in 20 seconds, failed again, try again in 40 seconds, etc.

Btw have you guys tried using LuaJIT?

data.title: Modify upgrade rules to match #8658 for rules older than 2015-07-11
data.body:
#8658 made the extra `0` in `Modifier: 0, 0` unnecessary.

It may be more difficult to fix rules in between without the information lost by using more generic traits as of #8572.

data.title: Replace RenderBuilding derivatives (RenderSimple removal Part 2)
data.body:
This replaces the four traits inheriting `RenderBuilding` with solutions based on `WithSpriteBody`.

NOTE: The `WithSpriteMakeAnimation` trait is a temporary solution that was necessary to avoid having to replace `RenderBuilding` and its four derivatives in one massive PR. It will be removed (or rather, replace the current `WithMakeAnimation`) together with `RenderBuilding`'s removal, hence why there's no upgrade rule for this.

data.title: Added option to turn off rendering of target lines in the settings
data.body:
When disabled, they can still be seen by pressing the Alt key.

Supersedes #8630.
Closes #6915.

data.title: IndexOutOfRangeException when hitting invincible bridges
data.body:
I can reproduce this consistently on GDI04c and Nod01, not on regular maps, though. The difference will be that those bridges are made invincible like this:

``` yaml
^Bridge:
        DamageMultiplier@INVULNERABLE:
                Modifier: 0
```

data.title: Statistics show two chronosphere icons
data.body:
Map is the official Vegetation.
![stat](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6599106/8784387/8718ac64-2f2a-11e5-9488-ac87df535686.png)
